Topic.Title: Dear Shareholders.....

Message.Msg: Dear Stevie: Last summer, after I fired off my activist missive to you and the board, I was given certain assurances that things were changing at etrade. I appreciate your efforts in some areas, such as board organization. But most of the sigificant change that has taken place would have happened under any average management team, as certainly as an apple would fall from a tree. Based on your encouraging conversation in the summer of '11, i agreed to forbear in my activist pursuit. However, since the summer of 11, the stock price has fallen precipitously, and the company now faces deteriorating nim, and a continued challenging dart environment. It is now time to forgo your hopes snd dreams plan and fulfill your responsibilities and fiduciary duty. This cannot be a experiment to maintain salaries and positions. The majority of investors are now in loss positions despite your assurances last summer that a greater value could be derived independently. The management of etfc cannot ignore the financual position of the company and the macfo economic headwinds. At this time, the demand is simple. There is no longer time for expert analysis and backroom discussions regarding ultimate potential. The proof is in the pps, now 50% from last years levels. We expect that the company embark on a sale process immediately. Yours truly, Ken

Topic.Title: Dear Shareholders.....

Message.Msg: Dear Kenny, What you need to understand is that I don't care about the share price. I only hold a few shares in comparision to my annual take in salary and bonus. Even with this stock hitting a 152 week low, I have no interest in buying additional shares as that is not where I make my money. My new pitch is a long term turnaround. Over the next 10 years, I will bring in more than 60 million (without raises) and that dwarfs any buyout premium since I have so little stock and with a buyout I would have to take losses on all of those positions. I have managed to scare away any potiential buyers by my complete and total mis-management of this company Therefore, I will continue on my road of hunkering down, being quiet except for those prickly earnings calls I have to attend and collect my check every Friday. BTW, did you notice the President of the Bank left? I am currently trying to convince the BOD that the compensation that comes with me taking on that additional role should be given to me. Check back next quarter as I will report falling revenues with darts and nim lower, and I start to hint about a secondary offering of common stock to bolster our capital position on the backs of shareholders. Your truly, Stevie

Message.Msg: did you miss it that the gop healthcare tax add $1500 a year to a family health insurance premium to pay for bushcare at the ER? can you comprehend that much of that ER care could have been prevented or dealt with FOR MUCH less cost if the person had insurance and could just go to the doc instead of the ER? and the FACT IS that a colonoscopy costs in the $2K range and that it MOST CERTAINLY can nip a cancer in the bud, since part of that is cut out precancerous polyps........ So, why do you think it is wiser for millions of poor people to never have insurance and never be able to afford a colonoscopy, and instead arrive at the ER at age 50 or whatever, with lots of bleeding, an emergency that would require surgery and intensive care and then chemo........ get the picture? and the examples would be the same for heart surgery that could have been prevented with doc visits and statins, and on and on. you people are just disgrace, really. and furthermore, the ACA reduces the deficit, which is one reason the man who enacted the blue print for it , Romneycare, said of his mandate in Ma. that is the "responsible" thing to do. Is Mittens a liar?

Topic.Title: Romney's "let's insult the world" trip continues

Message.Msg: . . . . . . . . .. A US president must have both sense and sensibility. Mr. Romney has a business sense but may be in short supply for other senses and definitely lacks sensibility. It is only in the US that people believe that if you make it big in business, you are bestowed with other capabilities. Mr. Romney has proved time and again that although he may have shown immense success in a narrow business field (selling and buying businesses) he has shown utter ignorance in many fields essential to grasp the US domestic and foreign policy issues What surprises me most is that Mr. Romney was the Governor of Massachusetts and that executive experience is more valuable than that of running a business. Since he has disavowed many good decisions he took as the Governor, he is left nothing to bank on but his business experience that required a sharp, one dimensional approach to the goal of making money at the expense of other sensibilities. Mr. Romney’s insensitive comments in England and Israel are evidence of that.

Topic.Title: Romney's "let's insult the world" trip continues

Message.Msg: Let's not forget that whatever the political tactics of their leaders, the Palestinians as a people are individuals and families who mainly just want a chance to flourish. What Mr. Romney says about the Palestinians, he says about all of us who, despite hard work in difficult circumstances, may not have enjoyed the luck and opportunities and connections to fulfill our potential. I see in President Obama a confident, successful man with the virtue of gratitude. He knows he isn't where he is because he's a superman, but because he was able to find avenues for his excellence that are not always available to everyone who deserves a chance to achieve. He understands this both as an American and as a citizen of the world. Wars are caused by the greedy and arrogant, not by people who, like ordinary Palestinians, only want a reasonably happy life. Mr. Romney has repeatedly told us that he wants to lead only those who are motivated by a relentless need to acquire more and more, not those of us who aspire to peace and prosperity on a human scale for all.
